security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based routing skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown documentation and decision trees that guide AI agents. No scripts, network calls, file system access, or external commands are implemented. Risk factor evidence is empty as this skill only provides routing guidance.

content.user_title: Route WordPress tasks to specialized workflows
content.value_statement: Users need help navigating complex WordPress project structures and selecting appropriate development workflows. This skill automatically classifies WordPress codebases and routes tasks to the correct domain-specific skills, ensuring proper handling of plugins, themes, blocks, and core development.
actual_capabilities: Classifies WordPress project types (plugin, theme, block theme, WP core, Gutenberg)
Routes tasks to specialized domain skills based on project kind and user intent
Identifies test frameworks present (PHPUnit, Playwright, wp-env)
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Requires WP-Project-Triage script to be available for automated classification
Cannot route without clear project type detection
Does not perform WordPress development tasks itself

use_cases.title: Plugin Development Routing
use_cases.description: Route plugin development tasks to wp-plugin-development skill for hooks, settings, and REST endpoints

use_cases.title: Theme Development Routing
use_cases.description: Route theme tasks to wp-block-themes or wp-plugin-development based on classic or block theme approach

use_cases.title: WP Core Contribution
use_cases.description: Route WordPress core contributions to wp-core workflows with proper PHPUnit and build tooling

prompt_templates.title: Basic Routing
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the wordpress-router skill to classify this WordPress project and tell me which skill to use for my request.

prompt_templates.title: With Project Context
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the WordPress router on this project to identify its type, available tooling, and route my request to the appropriate skill.

prompt_templates.title: Intent-Based Routing
prompt_templates.prompt: Given my WordPress project type and intent to [specific task], use wordpress-router to determine the correct domain skill and approach.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Skill Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Use wordpress-router to analyze my [plugin/theme/core] project and create a workflow plan that may involve multiple specialized skills.

output_examples.input: I need to add a REST endpoint to my WordPress plugin

best_practices: Use this skill at the start of every WordPress task for proper routing
Verify detected versions and tooling before starting implementation
Follow the guardrails checklist before making any changes
anti_patterns: Skipping routing and directly using a domain skill without classification
Assuming project type without running triage detection
Ignoring version constraints that affect development approach

faq.question: Which WordPress project types does this skill support?
faq.answer: Plugins, classic themes, block themes, block plugins, Gutenberg monorepo, WP core, and full site repos.

faq.question: What workflows can this skill route to?
faq.answer: Interactivity API, Abilities API, block development, REST API, WP-CLI, testing, and performance optimization.

faq.question: Is WP-CLI required to use this skill?
faq.answer: Some workflows require WP-CLI, but basic routing works without it. The skill detects WP-CLI availability.

faq.question: Does this skill access any files or data?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based routing guide. It describes what other skills should read for classification.

faq.question: How does triage detection work?
faq.answer: The skill references an external wp-project-triage script. This skill provides the decision tree for interpreting results.

faq.question: Can this skill be used with other WordPress skills?
faq.answer: Yes. It is designed to route to specialized WordPress skills like wp-block-development, wp-plugin-development, and wp-testing.
